segments.text: What experiences did you have with the low-income government?
Okay, well, a lot of our, well, first of all, all of our projects had to be approved by them.
Secondly, in order to kind of reinforce this image that, you know, it was them that was actually giving all of this aid to the local people.
In other words, it was the American government giving aid to the royal government, which was then handing it over to...
The people that a lot of the projects, in fact, almost all the projects I worked on, had to have not only law government approval, but law government involvement.
Now, some of the places I worked, there were, in effect, no law government officials or next to none, and it was in part because either the areas were too primitive or too unsafe.
In other places where I worked, they were all over the place, and...
A couple of jobs that I worked while I was there, I worked daily with somebody in the Lao government.
I helped do a census in between the time I got run out or shot out of this area and was waiting for a new field assignment.
They decided that they ought to put me in a city where it was nice and safe so I could calm down a bit.
In the meantime, they could find me something new back out in the countryside.
So I worked, oh, I've forgotten how long it was, about eight weeks, I guess, with a Lao government project in which they were doing the first census of the second largest city in the country.
And in fact, it was more the Lao government's project than ours and mine.
since I got in at the last minute my role, and it was pretty minimal.
And then there were other times in which I wasn't working with government officials so much directly, but there would be a local military commander who would be basically the kingpin of the area.
And we would, in effect, have to get his permission to do things.
And in one case in particular, a place where I worked 14 months,

The guy wanted it to be very clear to local people that we were, that he was a top dog there, and that anything that we, the two Americans did there, was only done because he had given his permission.
And so we had to learn to basically go through a kind of public ritual with the guy.
In fact, he enjoyed giving the impression that the things we were working on were his ideas.
And again, that was just something that I had to learn to live with.
He was kind of a jerk, although given the kinds of military commanders that were around, he was, in a lot of ways, a lot more benign than a lot of the others.
But he was no knight in shining armor.
At any rate...
we frequently had to go to him and convince him that something we wanted to do was a good idea.

That often meant literally getting drunk with a guy and after a time you could convince him to do almost anything and then he would sort of publicly announce that he had decided to you know either dig wells or
you know, grow rice or whatever it was we wanted to do, and then he would say something like, well, you know, the two Americans are going to run this.
But it all had to appear to locals, at least on the surface, that he was coming up with all these ideas, and he was basically delegating us to do kind of the dirty work.
So we were involved in that fashion, and then
Last but not least, we were somewhat dependent on the local military and commanders for our safety.
Although when I was attacked, we were within 200 yards of a military camp and it didn't stop people from coming into our backyard and taking a shot at us.
And having military protection didn't
keep this 19-year-old kid from being killed four miles from where I live.
And later on, a boat driver within a mile of my house being assassinated.
In fact, to protect us, in one of the places I worked, they put a minefield right behind our house because we were right on the edge of a jungle.
And one of the things that eventually drove us away from that place was that...
There was a lot of activity going on, and animals would set off mines at night, and we had gotten so gun-shy.

Increasingly, our radius of operation had been shrunk because our safety was no longer guaranteed, and we were down to just a couple of miles from where we were living, and since most of the people we were working with on a daily basis were farther out than two miles from our
a home that the people we lived among most immediately were among the least cooperative.
So not being able to work and being scared to death all the time with animals tripping off lines at night, we finally left that particular place.
So our involvement with the Lao government was fairly extensive.
Oftentimes, not because we wanted to, but because we had very little choice.
We went ahead and did things, but we frequently had to include them in some fashion, or get their permission, or that sort of thing.
What was the attitude of the U.S. government towards the Irish?
Well, I mean, I guess the official policy was to keep
the country from falling into communist hands.
Sort of unofficially, the attitudes vary widely.
Like I said, some of the people that I worked for within AID were former volunteers.
Some of them were like us in IBS, tend to be neutralists and were there simply to help the people.
There were also people within AID who were hawks with regard to the war.
One guy I worked for sort of indirectly used to look at the map of Laos and say, gee, look at all this rice land.
Wouldn't the Chinese just love to have their hands on it?
It's a good thing we're here kind of thing, in other words.
You could surmise from that that if we weren't there, the Chinese would, the communist Chinese would take over the country because of the rice land.
It was always kind of a
A joke to me because Laos is almost 80% mountainous.
There's very little rice land there.
It's really not worth taking over.
It's more of a burden.
One of the reasons we were paying almost 100% of the royal government's daily bills is because there was no natural resource base.
And now the Soviet Union is having to do what we were doing
for the Royal Lao government, they're having to do for the Communist government.
I mean, those people are dealing with the same resource base, which is non-existent.
And so, you know, just a country without any kind of sound financial basis for existing.
What was that to you, the Russian people, for the U.S. government?
Well, you know, the people I dealt with, the imperialists,
It's one of the things that was hard to talk to people about because a lot of them were unsure about who I was exactly.
And I also gathered that most local people were interested in local things, not national.
Most people didn't have any kind of national identity or even sense of citizenship.
Their world tended to be a very small, isolated place
Valley, most of them were isolated from the outside world.
I mean, we were flying in, that kind of thing.
They didn't have cars or donkeys or horses, so they, for the most part, didn't know much about the outside world.
So an awful lot of them were pretty indifferent towards the American government.
They knew that the American government was in the country.
Many of them just assumed that...
the American government was there in the same capacity that the French were.
In other words, we had come and taken over.

A lot of people weren't bothered by that because, again, it didn't touch, as long as it didn't touch on their everyday life, they didn't much give a damn what was going on in the city or somewhere else because it didn't affect their everyday attempts to survive.
There were some people...
who did have a sense of nationalistic feeling and were anti-American, just like they were anti-French prior to the French leaving the place.

And then there were people, I even had a guy working for me, who said, gee, I'm glad you guys took over our country, because eventually I'll be able to become an American citizen and go to the United States.
So it was really kind of a mixture of viewpoints.

But I found that among local military types, for instance, most of them were people who were drafted at gunpoint by one side or the other, and frequently they wound up changing sides from one side to the other, either voluntarily or involuntarily.
And I found that even among the troops, there wasn't much of a commitment to one side or the other.
There wasn't, again, any kind of sophisticated understanding of...

You know, the American government or communism or democracy was frequently, well, you know, I was fighting for this side because they were the ones that caught me in the field while I was flying and said, you either fight for us or we'll shoot you on the spot.
And both sides were doing that.
I talked to people who had fought for the communists and had switched sides, and it was because the communists couldn't give them uniforms and didn't feed them
and the other side did.
So, for the most part, people, at least at the local level, weren't very ideological.
Occasionally, you'd run across somebody whose family had been abused in some fashion or another by one side or the other, and so they had a kind of a personal, you know.
I met a guy who was fighting on the Lao government side whose family had been killed in a French bombing
raid and had fought for the communists for a long time.

And then he was sent to North Vietnam for further training and was so upset by what he saw that he decided that even though he didn't like the French or the Americans that much, that they were the lesser of the two evils.
So there was really a real mix of feelings.
There wasn't any kind of uniform.
But I'd say the vast majority of people didn't care much one way or the other.
when I went to a lot of areas, especially when I was just learning languages and didn't speak too well and wasn't easily understood.
Most people just ignored me.
I worked at the first place I had any chance to stay long enough to do anything.
At first, most adults wouldn't talk to me at all.
And I don't think it was so much fear as it was just kind of indifference.
And so for a long time,
A lot of kids, I had a kerosene-operated refrigerator, which I could make ice, and I would give ice to kids.
And so they would hang around, and they would teach me.
I'd get a chance to practice my language, and they were teaching me more vocabulary and so on and so forth.
And they would kind of follow me around, and these kids got the nickname of being the Americans' Little Soldiers.
These kids would kind of troop behind me in a line.
Well, again, most of them were indifferent to it.
They didn't get much out of it.

Even though there was an elected parliament and that sort of thing, most of the places I worked, people were either so isolated they had never had a chance to vote, or they did, but it was kind of meaningless to them.
There were, again, some people who didn't like the Lao government because it had interfered in their lives in some fashion.
And then I guess there were others who felt some loyalty to it because they had gotten some specific benefit.
But again, in a country that's, in effect, as backward as one like Laos, most people just didn't have experience with government.
The country was just too poor.
for there to be very many government officials out and among the local people.
Everybody knew who the king was, and the king was very popular.
A reproduction of his photograph was in just about every house that I was ever in.
But the king was a figurehead.
In terms of the real government, a lot of people didn't know who.
who was even in charge of them.
Did this attitude carry over towards the Vietnamese people?
Well, most of the people, most of the Lao that I knew, their emotions towards the Vietnamese could be summed up with one word, and that was fear.
Most people I knew were afraid of the Vietnamese.
partly for historical reasons and partly for contemporary ones.
Historically, the Vietnamese have made inroads into Laos.
The Vietnamese have been historically expansionistic.
So have the Thai, and between the Thai and the Vietnamese, Laos being rapidly gobbled up.
The French came in and made a colony out of Laos largely to keep it out of the hands of the British.
Nobody really wanted Laos because there's nothing there.
It's a money-losing kind of a proposition.
On the other hand, the French had Cambodia and Vietnam, and the British were in Burma, and they didn't want the British in Laos and then have the British right next door.
And so there was a French explorer,

who did some mapping of the country, and it was he and some government officials in France who convinced the French government in the late 19th century that Laos was worth basically colonizing, but the French never invested very much money into the place.
Did you ever have any experience with U.S. troops?
The only experience I had was when I was evacuated
Well, I had a couple.
I was evacuated by American soldiers flying a couple of helicopters when I was shot at during my first temporary assignment.
And then one time we had again made one of our daily radio check-ins.
We had to do it twice a day.
We had mentioned some
attack that we had heard about that had happened about 10 miles from us.
And we just, again, reported it because we felt like we needed to keep tabs on this sort of thing for military purposes.

We were, again, reporting this kind of thing so that there was some sort of pattern formed and somebody who knew more about military matters than we did could say, well, you know, it looks like things are heating up.
You guys better get out of there.
Somebody wouldn't say that.
Well, one time when both the guy that I was working with and I were in the capital for R&R, they made us come out the bush about every six weeks or so, at least for a weekender to relax.
And we were called into an office.
One of our aid supervisors took us over to an obscure little office on aid compound.
There were a couple of guys in there with American...
military uniforms on, and they started quizzing us thoroughly about this mortar attack and ultimately accused us of being liars because they said, well, based on our information, this never happened.
And we said, look, we weren't there.
We just report what we heard.
But they were, for some reason, very upset with us.
But it was quite clear at that time that the American military was monitoring the calls that we made to our aid
supervisors, and they were using information that we were passing along for our safety purposes, you know, for their own purposes.
And in some of the bars I wound up, I met embassy guards.
Every day we could see American fighter bombers flying into Laos, and it was pretty clear that they weren't flying
given the direction they were flying.
They weren't flying to North Vietnam.
They were flying to somewhere in Laos.
And it turns out that we were illegally bombing Laos, not only during the time I was there, but before I was there and after I was there.
And I have learned, subsequent to my being there, that we dropped more bombs on Laos, more tonnage of bombs on Laos than we actually did on the two Vietnams.
Did you have any experience with the Vietnamese troops?
No, other than it may have been Vietnamese troops who shot at us.
You know, we knew at the time in places where we were working that there were Vietnamese advisors working with the local communist forces.
But I never, thank God, met any of them because if I would have gotten that close to them, I wouldn't be alive.
There were Vietnamese...
all over Laos who were there as immigrants.
In fact, the entire middle class of Laos, in terms of merchants, were either Chinese, Indian, Pakistani, or Vietnamese.
There were hardly any indigenous or Lao merchants.
They were rare indeed.
So a lot of restaurants I ate at were run by Vietnamese.
Stores I bought things in were run by Vietnamese.
But that was really the only direct contact I had with them.
Well, things were deteriorating rapidly.

When I left, it was pretty clear that, you know, the Vietnam War was not going well for the United States, and it was the Civil War in Laos, you know, the two sides being backed by the Vietnamese and Americans, respectively.
that the Vietnamese backside was winning.
And apparently it was because the Vietnamese were just tough individuals.

There were all sorts of stories about when a Lao outpost would hear that they were going to be attacked and would hear that the troops that were going to attack them contained Vietnamese, they would just bug out.
They would take off because...
They were afraid.
I never witnessed this, but there were stories about this all the time.
And I did know that in some places...
Okay.
Let's see.
Oh, yeah.
Okay.
So it was clear that the other side was winning.
By the time I left, IBS has a
voluntary group had pulled itself out of rural programs.
We had just too many people being killed.
We couldn't protect ourselves anymore.
Before I left, I lost another couple of friends, and that was kind of the straw that broke the camel's back.
Our organization sort of got together and decided to tell the American

embassy, what we would do and not do, and it was pretty much unacceptable to them, and so they basically eliminated all of our field positions, and they kept for the remainder of the time that the American aid program was there, which was up until about 1975, only school teachers.
So, you know, when I left, that process was underway.
Well, I was sort of against it when I got there, and by the time I left, I was really against it.
I mean, I wasn't a supporter of the communists.
I didn't think they were, and I didn't think it was especially desirous that they take over.
On the other hand, local people didn't seem to care one way or the other.
And for a lot of local people, the communist government wasn't going to be any worse than
what they were having to deal with when they dealt with the royal Lao government.
But I basically felt like if the Lao weren't willing to do a better job of defending themselves, we couldn't do it for them.
A lot of people spent time trying to propagandize and basically warn the Lao people what they could expect, and it just
I guess, wasn't believed or people didn't care enough.
So I sort of felt like, you know, the communists are going to take over.
There's not much that can be done about it.
And probably the best thing for all is just for the war to end as fast as possible.
You know, put an end to the killing that was going on.
There wasn't a lot of death in Laos because, as I've tried to indicate, though,
the Lao went out of their way to fight, out of their way to avoid fighting the Vietnamese.

And in a couple places I worked, the story was that the two sides sort of let one another know on what days they were going to be in certain areas, and that way the other side could avoid stumbling into that area and running across the other guys and then being forced into a firefight.
And that

Those, you know, again, I don't have any verification of this, but just kind of my feeling about people there and things that they said gave me the idea that those stories weren't too far-fetched, that people really weren't involved in the war.
They were draft, you know, the vast majority of people were draftees into something they didn't give a damn about, and their main goal in life was to survive, you know,
to avoid any kind of life-threatening situation that they could, and to get out of the military as fast as possible and go back to farming.
So, you know, with those kinds of orientations, I mean, that's what they wanted.
They wanted the war over with, and so I felt like the war ought to wind down as rapidly as possible.
And it dragged on another...
five years after I left, or four years, and then there was an armistice.

In fact, I managed to go back in 1973, and there was kind of a rough peace, and I was actually able to travel to places on the ground, you know, in public transportation that I'd never been able to visit when I worked there officially.
In such a fashion, I would have been shot, but under the circumstances, I was actually able to go about
100 miles into the jungle to some places I'd work, in effect by taxing.
That is all the questions I have.
Is there anything that we have not talked about that you'd like to talk about?
Well, I can't think of anything.
Oh, I wanted to mention something.
My draft board was in Pasadena, California, which is, there are several places in California that are famous for their conservatism.
Pasadena, California is one of them.
That's where my draft board was located.
And they had, as I said when we started, told me, no, sure, go off for two years and do your thing.
You're going to have to come back after two years, and then you're going into the Army.
But at the end of my two years, of course, the war was still going on,
And so I asked to stay a third year.
I knew that unless there was some kind of letter to my draft board, they were going to say, now you're done playing good guy.
You've now got to do what everybody else of your age and sex does, and that's join the military.
While I was working in an area, there were only two of us, and it was indeed a place that had once been in the hands of the communists.
And so the guy that I worked for

simply wrote a letter to my draft board saying that I was one of two young Americans living in an area recently taken out of the hands of the communists, and we were the only two representatives of the American government there.
And I got a letter back from the draft board saying that I was permanently deferred.
In other words, what in fact they were saying is that what you're doing is, as far as we're concerned, the equivalent of going to Vietnam
And so stay there.
We're not going to draft you.
So I stayed another year.
It turns out that right after that happened, we had to evacuate.
The area was just too unsafe.
And I worked in another place, which eventually became too unsafe and finally wound up in a city the last few months while I was there.
And I guess that was it.
Thank you very much for interviewing with me.
You're welcome.
I enjoyed it.
I did, too.
